item.title: Italy cable car fall: 13 dead after accident near Lake Maggiore
item.description: The accident happened on the Stresa-Alpine-Mottarone cable car near Lake Maggiore in northern Italy.

item.title: Covid: UK passes 60m jabs milestone after 762,000 in a day
item.description: Health chief urges people to get their second jab, as more than 760,000 doses are given in a day.

item.title: Coronavirus: Patel denies No 10 pursued herd immunity policy
item.description: The home secretary rejects a claim by ex-aide Dominic Cummings that ministers wanted the virus to spread.

item.title: Belarus diverts Ryanair flight to arrest journalist, says opposition
item.description: European nations demand the dissident's release, after the Greece-Lithuania flight lands in Minsk.

item.title: Covid: Restaurants get creative in bid to plug staff shortage
item.description: Gift cards and bonuses are being used to fill vacancies as the hospitality sector emerges from lockdown.

item.title: Lisa Shaw: BBC Radio Newcastle presenter dies aged 44
item.description: Colleagues and listeners remember a "true professional" known for her humour and infectious laugh.

item.title: Scotland's lord advocate and solicitor general resign
item.description: James Wolffe QC and Alison Di Rollo QC say they will remain in post until replacements are appointed.

item.title: Damiano David: Eurovision winner denies taking drugs during event
item.description: The lead singer of the winning Italian band MÃ¥neskin dismisses online speculation about cocaine use.

item.title: BBC's reputation highly damaged by Diana interview report, says Patel
item.description: The report into the Diana interview is a "significant moment" for the corporation, home secretary says.

item.title: New border scheme aims to make UK safer
item.description: People coming to the country without a visa or immigration status will need a permit, the government says.

item.title: Human rights body leaves Stonewall diversity scheme
item.description: The Equality and Human Rights Commission says the LGTB group's scheme is not "best value for money".

item.title: In pictures: DR Congo's Mount Nyiragongo erupts, sparking mass evacuation
item.description: Thousands flee their homes in the Democratic Republic of Congo after a volcano erupts near Goma city.

item.title: Kate Garraway: 'My husband is devastated by Covid'
item.description: The TV presenter says Derek Draper still "can't really move" after coming home from hospital.

item.title: Eiffel Tower art and a new plane fuel - stories you may have missed
item.description: From Eiffel Tower art to cooking-oil plane fuel, here are some stories you might have missed this week.

item.title: Ultra marathon record-breaker shares secrets of Pennine Way success
item.description: Ultra-marathoner John Kelly, who ran the Pennine Way in under 60 hours, shares his secrets of success.

item.title: 'Did weak wi-fi password lead the police to our door?'
item.description: A young family had their computers and phones seized after, it seems, their router was hacked.

item.title: Glastonbury: Emily Eavis says she is 'so sorry' after technical issues derail live-stream
item.description: Organisers made Saturday's live-stream freely available after thousands were locked out of the virtual concert.

item.title: Glastonbury live-stream delivers a rush of nostalgia in the face of failure
item.description: The concert brought back fond memories, despite technical problems disrupting the live-stream.

item.title: Italy wins Eurovision: 'Rock and roll never dies'
item.description: Italy's MÃ¥neskin have won the Eurovision Song Contest 2021 with their entry, Zitti e Buoni.

item.title: Guatemala disappeared: Reuniting families with the remains of loved ones
item.description: Thousands are still searching for their loved ones 25 years after Guatemala's armed conflict ended.

item.title: Postcards: Londoners' lockdown secrets revealed
item.description: Eleanor Tattersfield sent out postcards asking people to divulge their lockdown secrets.

item.title: Your pictures on the theme of 'woodland walk'
item.description: A selection of striking images from our readers around the world.

item.title: âI have dementia, but Iâm still here, Iâm still meâ
item.description: Chris Higgins was diagnosed with dementia in lockdown after his wife noticed a change in his behaviour.

item.title: Inside Russia's Trefoil military base in the Arctic
item.description: BBC Moscow correspondent Sarah Rainsford gets rare access to the Russian military base, known as Arctic Trefoil.

item.title: Eurovision 2021 in pictures: The best of the ceremony
item.description: A look at some of the acts who performed on stage at this year's show in Rotterdam.

item.title: Could my mumâs toaster help me care for her?
item.description: An emerging technology allows carers to remotely monitor a vulnerable relative's energy usage.

item.title: Jon Cruddas: Labour guru's plan to win back the working class
item.description: Veteran Labour thinker Jon Cruddas says the answer to the party's woes is staring it in the face.

item.title: Does a $75m settlement make up for three decades in prison?
item.description: Two brothers have received a $75m payout over their wrongful 1983 murder conviction.

item.title: 'Miss, what's a duck?' Schools tackle nature-deprived kids
item.description: 'Miss. What's a duck?' The question that convinced one school to adopt nature-friendly learning.

item.title: Pregnancy after baby loss: 'We felt guilty for being excited'
item.description: After losing their son hours after he was born, Iona and Luke had mixed emotions about getting pregnant again.

item.title: India coronavirus: A tribal area had oxygen while cities gasped
item.description: The poor district of Nandurbar was prepared for a deadly second wave - unlike the rest of India.

item.title: Liverpool 2-0 Crystal Palace: Sadio Mane double seals Champions League qualification
item.description: A Sadio Mane double helps Liverpool beat Crystal Palace and seal Champions League qualification at Anfield.

item.title: Verstappen takes title lead from frustrated Hamilton with Monaco win
item.description: Red Bull's Max Verstappen takes a dominant victory in the Monaco Grand Prix to wrest the championship lead from Mercedes driver Lewis Hamilton.

item.title: Aston Villa 2-1 Chelsea: Blues lose but seal top-four finish
item.description: Chelsea secure a place in next season's Champions League despite losing to Aston Villa, Thomas Tuchel's side sealing a top-four place ahead of Leicester City.

item.title: Leicester City 2-4 Tottenham: Foxes miss out on Champions League after defeat
item.description: Leicester are denied a place in the Champions League for the second season running with Gareth Bale scoring two late goals to give Tottenham victory on a dramatic final day in the Premier League.

item.title: Fury signs Wilder contract as fight agreed for 24 July
item.description: British world heavyweight champion Tyson Fury signs his contract to face Deontay Wilder for a third time on 24 July.

item.title: Can two households travel in one car? And other questions
item.description: We answer some of your questions about England's roadmap out of lockdown, and other Covid-related issues.

item.title: Unemployment rate: How many people are out of work?
item.description: The pandemic has seen many people lose their jobs - but not as many as expected

item.title: Covid-19 in the UK: How many coronavirus cases are there in your area?
item.description: Explore the data on coronavirus in the UK and find out how many cases there are in your area.

item.title: Lockdown rules: What are the restrictions in your area?
item.description: Use our search tool to find out about coronavirus rules and restrictions where you live.

item.title: What are the rules for travelling to green, amber and red list countries?
item.description: Foreign holidays are now possible, but travellers must follow strict rules on their return.

item.title: What are the rules for weddings and can I hold a reception?
item.description: Restrictions on weddings have been eased across the UK - so how can you now celebrate?

item.title: Covid: How should I protect myself from Covid now?
item.description: What are the actions we can take to reduce our risk of catching the virus?

item.title: Covid map: Coronavirus cases, deaths, vaccinations by country
item.description: Key maps and charts explaining how the virus has spread around the world.

item.title: UK holidays: When and where can I go.... and who with?
item.description: The rules on having a holiday in the UK have been relaxed - but restrictions remain.

item.title: Covid: What's the roadmap for lifting lockdown?
item.description: Lockdown restrictions will ease in Northern Ireland, following rule changes in England, Scotland and Wales

item.title: Restaurants and pubs are reopening inside, but what are the rules?
item.description: Pubs have reopened inside, but there are still Covid rules for customers to follow.

item.title: Covid vaccine: How many people in the UK have been vaccinated so far?
item.description: The logistics of vaccinating millions of people across the country, as more than 37 million people receive at least one dose.

item.title: Lockdown easing: Virus experts tell us what they will (and won't) be doing
item.description: How will scientists use their new-found freedoms when Covid restrictions are eased on Monday?

item.title: Covid: When will I get the vaccine?
item.description: People in their 20s and 30s are now being offered a Covid vaccine as the UK rollout continues.

item.title: Covid: How do I get a lateral flow or PCR test?
item.description: Everyone in England and Scotland is being encouraged to take rapid coronavirus tests regularly.

item.title: Covid inquiry: What is it and how will it work?
item.description: An independent public inquiry has been announced, but how will it work?

item.title: Covid-19 vaccines: Why some African states can't use their vaccines
item.description: African countries have struggled to get vaccines, but some now plan to throw away thousands of doses.

item.title: Covid Indian variant: Where is it, how does it spread and is it more infectious?
item.description: B.1.617.2 is dominant in some parts of the country - but it doesn't have to be cause for panic yet.

item.title: Coronavirus: When can we stop wearing face masks or face coverings?
item.description: Rules are relaxing, but masks are still needed in some settings - here's where and why.

item.title: Covid: Which areas are being mass tested for variants?
item.description: People who live, work or travel in various parts of the UK are being urged to get a Covid test.

item.title: What are the India, Brazil, South Africa and UK variants?
item.description: In some parts of the UK coronavirus cases are rising due to a variant from India that spreads more easily.

item.title: Covid: What refund rights are there for holidays abroad?
item.description: Quarantine-free overseas holidays will be possible after 17 May, but what rights do you have if plans or rules change?

item.title: Covid-19: Five ways to make hugging safer, from the experts
item.description: Millions of people will be able to hug loved ones again from Monday. But can you minimise the risk?

item.title: India variant: Why was India not put on the red list sooner?
item.description: India was put on the travel ban list two weeks after Pakistan and Bangladesh.

item.title: Indian variant: What's causing the spike in Bolton?
item.description: The town has seen a sharp spike in Covid cases - driven by the emergence of the Indian variant.

item.title: Covid: Should I be working from home or going back to the office?
item.description: As lockdown restrictions ease gradually across the UK, what are the rules about returning to work?

item.title: Covid: Who can you hug and meet up with from Monday?
item.description: Guidance on hugging close friends and family is being relaxed in England and Scotland.

item.title: River Nene: Croquet match decides river's pronunciation
item.description: One team says "Nen", the other says "Neen", and they call it off after a battle with mallets.

item.title: Llandudno's Kashmiri goats invited to I'm A Celeb castle
item.description: They wreaked havoc in Llandudno - now they have been invited to the Welsh home of I'm A Celebrity...

item.title: Charlie Bit My Finger video to be auctioned as an NFT
item.description: The viral video of brothers Harry and Charlie - now 17 and 15 - will be taken off YouTube.

item.title: Marriage proposal at famous Scottish beach airport
item.description: Anna Pond said "yes" after spotting boyfriend Jamie Forde's message in the sand at Barra Airport.

item.title: Dragons' Den: Why new Dragon Steven Bartlett wonât be wearing a suit
item.description: Steven Bartlett is joining Dragons' Den but wants to do things his own way.
